awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: ICARUS - Index of Chamber Atmospheric Research in the United States
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a collaborative proposal to build an online, open-access, searchable, central repository for atmospheric chamber data in the United States called ICARUS (Index of Chamber Atmospheric Research in the United States).  Fundamental data obtained from chamber studies are routinely used as empirical inputs and constraints in atmospheric models. There are nine major U.S. research institutions participating in this project, including the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR).  This sustainable web-based infrastructure for storing, sharing, and using atmospheric chamber data will synergistically facilitate atmospheric chemistry research in the U.S.

The specific objectives of the project are to (1) provide a searchable public index of the chamber experiments from each participating research group; (2) archive past chamber data from each participating group under their indexed chamber experiment; (3) standardize chamber data reporting formats; (4) provide a uniform template for chamber metadata; and (5) streamline future data submissions.  The data products included in ICARUS are: (A) gas phase data that describes the time-resolved profiles of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) such as gaseous hydrocarbons, oxidized VOCs, oxidants (OH, O3, NO3), NOx, SO2, and other data; (B) particle phase data that describes yields of secondary organic aerosols (SOA) as well as optical properties, composition (detailed molecular and bulk elemental ratios), and chemical functional groups; (C) supporting information such as relative humidity, temperature, and light flux; (D) the experimental notes required to understand the data (such as reaction timing, mixing procedures, seed particle addition, and so on); and (E) vapor and particulate wall deposition rates that are needed to correct chamber data.  At the end of the 3-year project, the database will be transitioned to the Data Stewardship Engineering Team at NCAR.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
NSF Project Outcomes Report: Collaborative Research: ICARUS - Index of Chamber Atmospheric Research in the United States

 

The overarching goal of the project is to create a sustainable web-based infrastructure for storing, sharing, and using atmospheric chamber data in the U.S, called ICARUS (Integrated Chamber Atmospheric data Repository for Unified Science). Over the project period, our team of approximately 30 academic/government researchers and students/staff designed, developed, tested, and deployed a state-of-the-art website for managing and sharing atmospheric chamber data: https://icarus.ucdavis.edu. This website consists of (A) an access-controlled Data Intake portal and (B) a public Data Access interface. Each part of ICARUS have undergone detailed peer review by greater than 12 experts in the Atmospheric Chemistry community (both chamber experimentalists and atmospheric modelers), and updated to meet the needs of all users.

 

In the Data Intake portal, data providers register information about their chamber infrastructure, instrumentation, personnel contacts, experimental methods, and various “metadata” used to characterize the chamber environment and the experiments. The data providers then log the details of each experiments, link corresponding publications, and upload corresponding data from their instrumentation suite. This data intake process has been designed to be both rigorous (e.g., reactants traceable to PubChem and ACS, high metadata requirements, extensive vocabulary control, uniform data format standards, etc.) and facile (e.g., clonable entities such as datasets and instruments, visual interface objects such as buttons and drop down menus, extensive help text and error messages, etc.) to support efficiency while maintaining quality control. Each dataset is then assigned a persistent Digital Object Identifier (DOI) number that can be used to cite the data whenever it is used in publications. Data providers have the option of saving their data in draft mode, or embargo data until a later date.

 

The Data Access interface maximizes the discoverability of data by enabling partial word searches, smart sorting and filtering of datasets using 18 parameters, broad indexing with other search engines (e.g., Google, Web of Science), and automatic mirroring to NCAR’s GDEX Repository (https://gdex.ucar.edu/search.html?rpp=20&q=icarus). Version control is also tracked by NCAR, each assigned an internal tracking number. This data discovery process is tailored to the data users. For example, each filtering parameter and each data/metadata display section can be expanded or hid from view, and the website remembers the user preferences they are browsing. Users can also view (or hide) data in real time. Each instrumental data trace is visualized online Quick Plot function, which is fully interactive and fast (even for datasets with thousands of data points). Finally, the user can select one or multiple datasets to download as zip files using up to three mechanisms for data downloads, including a combined download queue.

 

ICARUS currently houses several hundred high-quality datasets and hundreds more characterization data files for diverse data user applications. At the end of this project, our team invited participation from any chamber research group in the United States and elsewhere in North America, with the intent to grow the database content beyond contributions from the initial pilot team. Help guides, documentation, programmatic tools, and reference information were made available on the website to help current as well as new members. The ICARUS management team aims to sustain high-quality data curation with open access data availability to all members of the Atmospheric Chemistry community for years to come.  

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2023
Modified by: Tran B Nguyen
